title: Melbourne's J'Aton Couture seek investor to conquer the world
text:
“Jacob is incredible at hand sewing and he’s fantastic with clients and consulting,” says Pittorino. “I absolutely hate hand sewing and I’m hopeless at it, but I love appliqueing, pattern making and graphic design. We both love the variety of creativity and technicality involved in our work.”

With nearly 200 client orders undertaken annually, anyone would think the designers now employ an army of staff to keep up. Not so. No matter if it’s a $125,000 commission for a wedding dress in the Middle East or fielding calls from the world’s most powerful female musicians to submit designs for their upcoming tour costumes, it is still just the two of them at the helm of all hands-on operations – with high stress and little sleep, naturally.

“We started J’Aton with so many clients before we had actually opened the doors,” Luppino explains. “We worked day and night without taking a breath and the business became bigger than us.” The brand’s rapid growth has only continued to escalate since then, largely due to the designers dressing some of the world’s most influential women: Kim Kardashian West, Jennifer Lopez, Beyoncé, Nicole Kidman, Kylie Minogue and Jessica Alba, to name just a few.

“Celebrities have a power that is second to none; J’Aton Couture exists today because of celebrity support,” Pittorino says. “But these celebrities and their stylists often think we’re much bigger than what we are in terms of our business operations. They think that coming to us is like going to one of the big European fashion houses that employ thousands of staff and have financial backers.”

We’re looking for the right investor, who appreciates quality and upholds our commitment to integrity in every aspect of the business. — Anthony Pittorino, J'Aton Couture

Over the past two decades, J’Aton Couture has struggled to find the right investor to expand the brand from its humble Melbourne origins into a revered force on the global stage. The designers say this is because Australians don’t truly understand the value of couture as an art form that must be nurtured. In an ideal world, an investor would support the designers in establishing an atelier in Paris or Milan, and a showroom in New York, the epicentre of operations for fashion and celebrity culture. Which raises the question: is Australia the right market for their work?

While there is seemingly no shortage of local and international investors intrigued by the J’Aton universe, the proposed business model of having the garments manufactured at a cheaper cost in India or China would breach the brand’s integrity.

“We could be rich tomorrow – a huge global brand – if we just said yes to unethical practices. We have millionaire and billionaire investors lined up, but we’re not interested,” Pittorino asserts. “We’re looking for the right investor, who appreciates quality and upholds our commitment to integrity in every aspect of the business, especially the ethical treatment of workers, which the industry is renowned for mistreating.”

Even to the undiscerning eye, a mere glance at a J’Aton creation would suggest it ought to be displayed behind glass in a Florentine museum. The crafting of a single gown takes more than 200 hours, with the designers doing all the fitting, cutting, sewing and hand-embellishing themselves. Each client becomes the muse-like subject of her own portrait, a vision of femininity brought to life by two masters of their craft.

Advertisement

Kylie Minogue in J'Aton Couture at the 2015 Qantas Australia Day Gala Dinner in London. Getty Images

Needless to say, Pittorino and Luppino’s shared Italian heritage and deep appreciation for the artisanal culture in which they grew up dwells at the heart of the entire brand, informing their approach to empowering the female identity.

“J’Aton reflects a strong European sensibility,” Luppino says, admitting that this evocation of Italian culture and craftsmanship through the duo’s work has, in fact, been detrimental to the brand at times over the past two decades. “The criticism of our work here in Australia as too ethnic or too overt has really impacted on us as designers.”

Nevertheless, it is the extent to which J’Aton embodies the decadent aestheticism of the Italian Baroque period that remains the brand’s inimitable mode of visual storytelling. Luppino and Pittorino were handcrafting works of “wearable art” in Australia long before the notion exploded into public consciousness through global exposure at events such as the Met Gala. To this day, a J’Aton creation ignites the imagination with a feast of sensory cues seamlessly mingled to evoke everything from a still-life nude portrait to a plate of blushing prosciutto slices. It takes a deep understanding of fashion’s relationship to the related discourses of fine art, food, music and film to truly appreciate a J’Aton creation.

Amid an archive of A-list commissions that leaves no bead or bodice unturned, the designers recall a gown created in 2007 for burlesque star Dita Von Teese as one of their most memorable. It was inspired by baroque artist Elisabetta Sirani and her painting Portia Wounding Her Thigh (1664), a work they perceived to have embodied the power of Von Teese’s femininity, along with her pain after splitting with then husband Marilyn Manson.

"We play it safe most of the time”: Jacob Luppino (left) and Anthony Pittorino share a sofa with a model in another of their dresses. Simon Schluter

“It was a living canvas dedicated to Dita’s evolving love story, tattooed with love quotes and hidden poems under layers of gathered tulle,” says Pittorino. “We wanted to empower and inspire her through the garment.”

With few women finding themselves in the fortunate position of personally experiencing the J’Aton dream, social media has been key in disseminating the designers’ work to a besotted fan base across the world. If you can’t wear a J’Aton gown, the next best thing is to fantasise about wearing one, via images on Instagram. When a bride or celebrity wears one of Luppino and Pittorino’s creations, it takes mere moments for pictures to end up on thousands of “inspo” accounts. While this hype has obviously been integral in achieving global exposure for the brand, it has come with significant challenges.

“Social media exposed us to a raft of designers out there reproducing our work in Third World countries and becoming filthy rich on our brand DNA. Today, designers are a click away from inspiration. Or is it interpretation?” he asks, wryly. “Any dress we do, someone on the other side of the world is now willing to copy it and charge half the price. We are losing at least $5000 to $10,000 a dress. That’s a lot of money.”

With bridal orders and private commissions making up most of the J’Aton clientele, the duo reflect upon an element of constraint on their creativity in always ensuring a brief is satisfied. “We don’t believe we have truly created pieces of wearable art in our garments,” Luppino says. “We fear we will be perceived as too ethnic, or that our clients will be ridiculed, so we play it safe most of the time.”

For two designers who have rarely given interviews in nearly three decades of working in the industry, this is a remarkable admission. A sense of mystery surrounds J’Aton; it’s an aura few Australian designers have been able to cultivate, and might even be perceived as a modern manifestation of the “myth of the artist” fantasy. There is a sense that, given the right timing, the right projects and perhaps the right investor, the full grandeur of J’Aton Couture would be revealed to the world.

The heritage issue of LUXURY is out on Friday, September 6 inside The Australian Financial Review. Follow LUXURY on Instagram.
description: Over the past 25 years, this design duo have dressed the likes of Beyonce, Kylie and J.Lo. The next step? Going global – but on their terms.
